content: Negotiating parties of the proposed Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement (ACTA) have until May 1, 2013, to sign the agreement. The ACTA would enter into force after the sixth instrument of ratification is deposited. Mexico signed the ACTA on July 11, 2012, requiring ratification in the Mexican Congress. The European Parliament voted against the ACTA on July 4, 2012, leading to suspensions in several EU member states. On February 22, 2012, the European Commission paused the ACTA ratification process and sent it to the European Court of Justice for review. The European Union and 22 member states signed the ACTA on January 25, 2012. In October 2011, several countries including Australia, Canada, Japan, Korea, and the United States signed the agreement. The final version of the ACTA text was released in May 2011 after nearly three years of negotiations. The Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement (ACTA) was publicly released in its final version in October 2010 after nearly three years of negotiations. It is a new agreement aimed at combating intellectual property rights infringement, focusing on trademarks and copyrights enforcement. The ACTA was negotiated by several countries including the United States, European Union, Japan, South Korea, and others to address emerging IPR issues not adequately covered in the WTO TRIPS Agreement. The ACTA establishes a legal framework for IPR enforcement, including provisions on civil enforcement, border measures, and criminal enforcement for trademark counterfeiting or copyright piracy. Negotiations concluded in October 2010, with countries having until May 1, 2013, to sign the agreement. All negotiating parties, except Mexico and Switzerland, have signed the agreement, with domestic ratification procedures to follow. The idea of negotiating the ACTA was conceived in 2006 by the United States and Japan to combat counterfeiting and piracy. In 2006, the United States and Japan proposed the ACTA to combat counterfeiting and piracy. Negotiations involving various countries began in 2007 and concluded in October 2010. The final round was held in Japan in October 2010, where a largely finalized text of the agreement was produced. The agreement was to be submitted to respective authorities for approval. On October 1, 2011, several countries signed the ACTA agreement, with additional countries expressing support and preparation to sign. The ACTA establishes a legal framework for IPR enforcement, including general obligations for enforcement, civil enforcement, border measures, criminal enforcement, and enforcement in the digital environment. It requires effective enforcement action that provides expeditious remedies, avoids trade barriers, and ensures fair treatment. The civil enforcement section emphasizes proportionality in infringement seriousness and applicable measures. The civil enforcement section of the ACTA emphasizes the seriousness of infringement, third-party rights, and applicable measures. The ACTA emphasizes the seriousness of infringement and applicable measures for IPR enforcement, including judicial procedures, injunctions, damages, and destruction of infringing goods. The digital enforcement section addresses obligations for enforcing copyrights and related rights over digital networks, ensuring effective enforcement action against IPR. The enforcement procedures in the agreement focus on effective action against IPR infringement in the digital environment, including copyright infringement over digital networks.
